ed all the obvious considerations which contribute to the importance of a regular Christian Ministry to the Religion, the Morals, the Virtues and the happiness of a people— He alluded in general terms and without complaint to his own services during his connection with the Church for a space of not more than two years— He did not dwell upon the cause or motives of his own departure The occasion of which is an invitation from a Society in the City of New York The theme is copious and was discussed with great power in the Supreme Court of the United States by Mr. Daniel Webster about two years ago on the Trial of the Gerard College at Philadelphia— Mr. Knox Sermon without being perhaps equally comprehensive and eloquent was to me more affecting and affecting above all by the selection of the text— Dr. T. B. J. Frye dined with us and after dinner I attended at St John’s Church where Mr. Pyne read the evening Service for the fourth Sunday in Advent and Mr.preached from 1. Corinthians 9.24. part of the verse “So run that ye may obtain” the preceeding part of the verse is—“know ye not that they which run in a race run all but one receiveth the prize” Thus that which the Apostle exhorts the Corinthians, so to run that they may obtain it is the prize of the race— But the Preacher did not much attend to that part of the context which remarks that only one can obtain the prize and although the Discourse was not destitute of good sense and piety it made little impression upon my mind or I believe upon those of the Auditory in general— There was something lacking of an explicit meaning in the text itself which needed the explanation of the con-text even to be understood—
22. V.30. Fahrenheit Sunrise 20.

Mr. William H. Dietz called on one this morning with a letter signed by Jesse. E. Dow and himself as a Committee of the Board of Trustees of the 2d. Presbyterean Church of the City of Washington and a statement of accounts with balance of 75.99. due from me to them—they stated that deeply impressed with the sense of the obligations of that society to me they would have abstained from presenting me this Account but that their late Pastor Mr. Knox was to leave the City to-morrow and that they were under necessity of collecting a sum of money due to him At the last settlement of the Account with me on the 20th. December 1837—here was due to me $199.88— I have been charged from that time with forty dolls a year rent of the Rev. and thus the whole sum which I had lent to the
Society, to save them from dissolution has been absorbed and this balance brought to bear against me, while I have held the Pew almost without use during the whole time— I told him that I wished to surrender the Pew to the Society to be disposed of as they should think proper—and thereby score of the balance of their charge against me— They did not seem disposed to accept of this arrangement but left me saying they would make report of my proposal to the Board of Trustees— The widow of Mr. George Grahame came and requested a recommendation from me to the Secretary of the Navy Mr. Bancroft in behalf of her Son a youth of 16. years of age for a Midshipman Warrant which I readily promised her though my recommendation, can avail no farther than to have his name entered in the Books of the Department as one of the Candidates for the appointment. She said there was a rule that the number of midshipmen must be distributed among the states according to the number of their Representation in Congress and that her Son was entitled to be entered as belonging to the state of Missouri where an Uncle of his resided— Mr. Bancroft had been here this morning before Mrs. Grahame— I spoke to him in favor of Mr. Kavasales the Chaplain and mentioned his wishes to obtain a shore station at Norfolk or at Brooklyn Long-Island or if that should be inadvisable a leave of absence— Mr. Bancroft said that Mr. Kavasales had been treated with as much indulgence as any other Chaplain in the Navy but that the reports from the Commanding Officers of the Squadron in which he had served were unfavorable to him— That he was represented as inefficient and incompetent for the service required by his station, that he had performed little or no duty and that his conduct had not been unexceptionable in regard to his moral principles— I said that this was the first intimation that I had ever received of this last charge—that on the contrary I had understood from the Chief Clerk of the Department, that not a lisp against his moral character or conduct had been heard from any quarter—that if it was well founded I wished him to consider me as withdrawing any recommendation that I had heretofore given in his behalf and would never say another word in his favor—but that upon a charge of this nature I thought he was entitled to a hearing, that it must be made by a responsible person and duly investigated, if it was to be made the foundation of any denial of proper indulgence to him— That I had taken a deep interest in him from principles of humanity regarding him as a stranger an Orphan cast in his childhood upon the Charity of this nation by the Turkish massacre at Smyrna in which both his Parents had perished
and he himself was saved by the kindness of the Commander of our Squadron there at that time He was brought to this Country by him and educated for the Gospel Ministry at the Charge of a Religious and Charitable Association by whom he was first recommended to me— I had earnestly solicited his appointment as a Chaplain I was still earnestly solicitous that he should enjoy the advantages of his education and discharge faithfully the duties of his station that he should suffer no injustice from the Government of this Country but if there was any taint upon his morals I must withdraw any interposition in his favor— I could only require that he should have a fair and impartial trial— Mr. Bancroft said that he would require a formal Report concerning him from the Officers of the Squadron in which he had served— At the House the reading of the Journal of last Friday after some objection was commenced but soon suspended and dispensed with a message from the President was received in reply according to his English to the Resolution of the 25th. February last with Report from the Secretary of State with the correspondence of George W. Slacum late Consul of the United States at Rio Janeiro with the Department of State relating to the African Slave trade— It was read; laid on the Table and ordered to be printed— The House then proceeded to the Election of Chaplain and after some obstruction from John Pettit who finally asked to be excused from voting in which he was seconded by William Sawyer of Ohio both of them being excused the election was made there were thirteen nominations and at the third vote Revd. William A. Millburne was chosen— George W. Jones of Tennessee then moved to proceed to the election of a superintendant of the folding room. The Speaker at first said that this would require a vote of two thirds but afterwards changed his opinion and decided that the election might be made by vote of a majority— Hannibal Hamlin of Maine moved that the election should be made by Tellers— Timothy Jenkins of New York moved to lay Hamlins motion on the Table rejected by yeas and nays 57. to 90. but the House adjourned at three o’clock without making the election—or deciding in what manner it should be made— Shortly before 7. o’clock this evening Mr. John James Greenough came from the New England Society to accompany me to the United States Hotel where they had a Public dinner in celebration of the Anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth in 1620. I had received some days since an invitation from two Members of the Society to attend at this Festival—
but I had written an answer addressed to the President of the Society David A. Hall declining to attend on account of the state of my health and the inclemency of the weather.— Which Mr. Greenough undertook to deliver— Dr. Frye was here, and said that his Father and he were both going to the celebration.

Revd. Mr. Knox called on me this morning, and took leave of me on his departure for New York where he has received and accepted a call to be the Pastor of the tenth Presbyterean Church in that City.— He has been about two years Minister of the 2nd. Presbyterean Church here and like many of his predecessors is obliged to leave them from their inability to support a Minister in a comfortable state of existence— Mr. Knox made me a parting present of a book entitled Vital Christianity Essays and Discourses on the Religions of Man and the Religion of God by Alexander Vinet D.D. Professor of Theology in Lausanne Switzerland translated with an Introduction by Robert Turnbull Pastor of the Harvard Street Church Boston— A person whose name I think I never heard of before— It was ten minutes past twelve when I reached the Capitol this morning and the House of Representatives had already adjourned over to Saturday next There had been some difficulty in the House concerning the composition of the Committee of Claims— Joseph Vance of Ohio, had been first appointed Chairman of that Committee and had resigned— J. J McDowell of the same state had been appointed in his place and now declined serving on the Committee as being already appointed on two other Committees— He added that there were circumstances connected with the appointment of Committees of the House affecting his State which forbade him from serving on any Committee upon which his name was placed what those circumstances were he did not explain John R. J. Daniel of N.C. now Chairman of the same Committee stated that Stephens of Georgia had not attended the meetings of the Committee and as he was informed did not intend to attend them He moved therefore that Stephens should be excused from serving on that Committee and that a member be appointed in his place— It was objected that if Mr. Stephens was to be excused it must be at his own request and there the matter rested— From all this it appears that the Speaker has

given some disatisfaction by the composition of the Committees of the House— The assortment of my Petitions is not yet completed in the Clerks Office— After passing some time in it I went into the Library of Congress and took out the 3d. Volume of an English Translation of Eugene Sue Mystères de Paris the original Copy lent me by Mr. Hughes not being complete— In the Library I met Mr. Robert Dale Owen who enquired of me at what time I could make it convenient to attend a Meeting of the Select Committee on the Smithsonian bequest— This Committee was appointed last Friday on the Bill introduced by Mr. Owen and consists of seven members—Robert Dale Owen of Indiana, John Quincy Adams of Mass Timothy Jenkins of N.Y. George P Marsh of Vermont, A D. Sims of S.C. Jefferson Davis of Miss and David Wilmot of Pa—about as strange a Committee as could have been jumbled together— I told Mr. Owen that I would attend at any time and place desired by him— He proposed tomorrow at 10. o’clock to which I immediately acceeded but before naming the place of meeting he said, that upon reflection he thought it would be better to postpone the meeting till next week to which I also immediately agreed Morning visits from Mrs. Madison, Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Cutts, Miss Cutts and Miss Anna Payne—whom I had met before in the Library— Mr. Cutts was married on the 16. this month to Miss Hackly at Norfolk Virginia— In the evening I divided my time in reading a Chapter of Greenhow— History of Oregon and California—and several Letters on the National Institute Smithsonian Legacy the fine Arts and other matters connected with the interests of the District of Columbia—by John Carrol Brent republished in Pamphlet from the National Intelligencer where they appeared in the first half of the year 1844— I have received a Copy of this Pamphlet from the Author—

I omitted to mention yesterday that I met Mr Joshua Dodge in Pennsylvania Avenue who walked home with me and came in and spent half an hour here. This morning I called at the Navy Department where I found the Secretary Mr. Bancroft and told him that I came as a solicitor for a Lady Mrs. George Graham in behalf of her Son a youth of sixteen very desirous to obtain a midshipman’s warrant— Mr.
Bancroft objected that several relations of this Lady were already in the Pub Service and that being a resident of the Dist. Columbia from which there were already a great disproportion of their numbers in the naval service, it was scarcely practicable to allow them any further favors— I observed that Mrs. Grahame claimed the State of Missouri as the domicil of her Son Mr. Bancroft treated this pretension some what lightly observing that she had already advanced the same claim in behalf of the state of Pa. and that she had made personal application to the President to Mrs. Polk, to Mr. Bancroft himself and to every other person whom she supposed to possess any influence with him, but that he had not been able to find a sufficient justification for complying with her request— The earnestness of a Lady in soliciting for the benefit of her son the means of useful education and honorable existence in the service of his Country I observed were entitled to great indulgence and even to warm approbation if not to compliance— I discussed the matter for some time with Mr. Bancroft without apparently producing any impression upon his determination and on parting from him told him I should report to the Lady as the result of my commission from her that it was impossible to say no more graciously than the Secretary of the Navy had done— I received this day from Mr. E. Littell of Boston Six Volumes and ten separate numbers of Littells Living Age—a Periodical weekly Journal commenced on the 11th. May 1844—and continued down to the 6th. present month—a republication of select Articles, from all the principle periodical Journals published in England and in this Country a compilation very deserving of patronage—for which Mr. Littell has sent me a Petition to Congress which he requests me to present to the House of Representatives— I received from Mrs. T. Miller daughter of General Walter Jones a Pair of Worked Slippers to be made up— The Slippers are of black broadcloth worked in coloured worsteds—exquisitly perfumed together with a visiting card bearing the name of Mrs. T. Miller and in pencil writing as follows—“With the compliments of the Season, and best wishes for the happiness and health of our venerable and much esteemed Ex President”— With this Lady I can scarcely boast of the honor of having any acquaintance and I have only a very slight one with her husband Dr. Thomas Miller—of this City— My Grandaughter attended a small Party this evening at Mrs. Fleischman’s— All the remainder of the Family were at home—
Thursday 25 Dec. Christmas day—

After spending some-time of my principle present labor in assorting, filing, and preparing for presentation the numerous prevailing Petitions and Remonstrances against the admission of Texas as a State of this Union for the purpose of exercise and of returning sundry visits I walked forth and at the top of Pennsylvania Avenue met Mr. John Davis one of the Senators from Massachusetts to whose lodgings at the top of the Hill at Mrs. Whitwells whither I was bound— He told me that Mr. Grinnell and Mr. Winthrop with his Son were gone to N.Y. I then went to Judge Cranch’s House where I found his daughters Mrs. Rufus Dawes—and Mrs. Brooks—and Mr. Waterston as a visitor The Judge himself had not returned from the Unitarian Church where the Christmas Day was solemnized by religious Services— I met the Judge with Miss Appleton returning from the Church At Coleman’s National Hotel I called to see Mr. Webster but found that he also had gone to the North— Returning home I had a visit from Mr. James Buchanan Secretary of State. He told me that he had formerly visited my father at Quincy and said that in speaking to him of some of the Tories during our Revolutionary War were men of great respectability fine Talents and excellent private character but that they were all deporably loyal an epithet which Mr. Buchanan said had greatly diverted him— We had Company to a Family dinner Mr. and Mrs. Frye with their Son the Dr. and Miss Frye a daughter of Mr. Frye’s brother on a visit to him from the state of Maine and Mr. Theodore L Moody also from the state of Maine, sometime settled in Alabama and now a Clerk in the Land Office— They also spent the evening here and for the first time for many years I took a hand at a Rubber at Whist— I finished reading this morning the Book of Genesis and among the very striking Properties of this first Book of the Holy scriptures I have been more impressed than I had ever been before with what is called the blessing of Jacob upon his children the Patriarch’s of Israel in the 49th. Chapter It is said that when upon his death bed he called unto his Sons and said “Gather yourselves together—that I may tell you that which shall befal you in the last days[”] There is a Prophecy for each of the twelve Sons without notice of what he had before said that each of the two Sons of Joseph Ephraim and Manassa should form a separate Tribe. But
of all these predictions there is not one excepting that of Joseph which can properly be called a blessing. The beginning of that of Ruben the eldest son is—“Unstable as water thou shalt not excel[”] and there is barely one of them but portends calamity and wickedness rather than blessing— This Prophecy is understood to be applicable not to the sons themselves but to their remote posterity the Tribes descending from them— The predictions are all obscure highly metaforical and not easily comparable with any fulfilment which afterwards happened to them— It is said for example Benjamin shall ravine as a Wolf in the morning he shall devour the prey and at Night he shall divide the Spoil— Now in the Book of Judges it is related that this Tribe of Benjamin was nearly exterminated in a Civil War with the other Tribes— In the 2nd. and third verses of the 21st. Chapter of that Book it is said “that the People came to the House of God and abode there till even before God and lifted up their voices and wept sore and said Oh Lord God of Israel why is this come to pass in Israel that there should be to day one Tribe lacking in Israel” This seems hardly a confirmation of the blessing of Benjamin by Jacob— The Tribe of Benjamin was indeed to some extent restored and the first King of Israel Saul was one of his descendants—but the fate of Saul himself and of all his posterity shows in glaring contrast to the prediction of the dying Jacob— The Tribe of Benjamin never recovered entirely from the War in which it had been so nearly extinguished— Of all the particulars of Jacob’s Prophecy that respecting Judah is the most remarkable— He calls him a “Lions whelp[”] and adds [“]from the prey my Son thou art gone up—he stooped down, he couched as a Lion and as an old Lion who shall rouse him up[”] and then the nex verse says [“]the sceptre shall not depart from Judah nor a Law giver from between his feet until Shiloe come and unto him shall the gathering of the People be” this is considered I believe by all the Christian Commentaters upon the scriptures as a Prophecy of the Advent of the Saviour Jesus Christ—and when I was a Student at Newburyport I heard a sermon by the Rector of the Episcopal Church at that place afterwards the first Episcopal Bishop in Massachusetts—delivered on Christmas Day on that text in which this position was maintained and which has dwelt upon my memory to this day— It was in the year 1787. or 1788. but it appears to me that the passage is not susceptible of that construction distinctly precluded by the tenor of the two following verses There is no sufficient explanation of the Grounds upon which the term Shiloe can be applied to Jesus Christ—nor is it apparent how it should be said that the Sceptre should not depart from Judah until he should
come— The Tribe of Judah having been carried into captivity into Babylone hundreds of years before the Advent of Christ—

A sleepless night or at least I was unconscious of losing the sense of wakefulness from the time when I went to bed last night till I arose this morning— I heard the clock below successively strike eleven, twelve, one, two three, and four— I supposed myself wholly awake from that time but did not hear the clock strike five or six, and found broad daylight much to my surprize and the clock striking seven and when I was not aware of any interval since I had heard the stroke of four— I must therefore have slept nearly three hours with a consciousness of being all the time awake— This condition of body and mind is not new to me— I have experienced it before but know not how to account for it— A morning visit from Mr. Truman & Mr. James Dixon Members of the House of Representatives from Connecticut, and I visited Mr. Wm. A. Mosely Representative from the Buffalo District of New York—he is confined to his chamber with a severe attack of inflammatory rheumatism and has been unable to attend the House nearly from the commencement of the Session—he is now recovering but thinks it will be a week or ten days longer, before he will be able to resume his seat— I had some conversation with him on the present state of Public affairs— He is a member of the Whig party the policy of which among the People appears to be concentrating itself upon a system of opposition to the present Administration on the ground of its propensity to War with Great Britain— Dangers of War and a very contemptuous estimate of the object for which they suppose the President is provoking it are the only theme upon which they dwell without sufficiently considering that their terrors and prognostics may furnish to Mr. Polk motives and pretexts for yielding to the pretensions of our adversary and sacrificing our own just claims to the Territory in dispute of which I think there is much greater danger than of a War for the maintainance of them— I commenced this morning the reading of the Book of Exodus, presenting the opening of a new Scene in contrast of those which had preceded through the Book of Genesis to its close— The vocation of Abraham and its consequences to himself and his family until their temporary establishment in the Land of Goshen under the Government of Egypt is now succeeded by the birth and surprising history of Moses the leader of the children of Israel to the promised Land of Canaan which he was not permitted himself to enter and to the system of Laws for their Government as a Nation which he received from the hand of Jehovah on Mount Horeb— I read also another chapter of Greenhows history of Oregon and California—

I was again restored to the blessing of sleep which came on me very soon after I retired to bed last night and continued till nearly Sun Rise this morning but my sleep was restless and I arose suffering much with rheumatism— Mr. Kavasalas called upon me again this morning and I told him the result of my interposition with the Secretary of the Navy in his favour— That there were complaints against him not only of incompentency for the performance of the duties of his station but even with regard to his moral conduct and I said that if there was any just exception against him in that respect I had assured Mr. Bancroft that I should cease for ever all farther interference in his behalf—but Mr. Bancroft had said that no specific charge or formal report against him had been made and I urged that if any charge existed against him to his disadvantage in the mind of the Secretary it should be made by a responsible person in specific terms and that he should be allowed a hearing in defence and justification of himself— Mr. Kavasalas said he was very sure that no such charge could be made, but that most of the Officers were his Enemies and especially those addicted to habits of intemperance and to the use of profane language of which he was sorry to say there was far too great a proportion and he named to me several from Post Captains down to Surgeons and Midshipmen who were notoriously intemperate from who he had received the most injurious and insulting treatment— I do not repeat their names here but I fear that his charges against them are but too well founded— He added he had no doubt that these same Officers were the same persons who had made these informal and unwritten charges against him which had indisposed the mind of the Secretary of the Navy towards him— I advised him to call upon the Secretary at the Department and to repeat in his own name the claim which I had made for him, that any charges against him should be specifically made and that he should have the opportunity of self defence to repel them— He left me and returned this evening with a sad report of his visit to the Secretary, who received him together with another person a stranger to him and treated him as he said with so much rudeness and insolence that he remained not more than three minutes in his Office and withdrew from it in total disappointment, that Mr. Bancroft upon his entering the Office had accosted him with an air of anger and demanded what he would have—he answered that he was desirous of obtaining from him a private interview, that Mr. Bancroft had replied that he must speak out; what he wanted, or that he must commit it to writing. A short dialogue ensued in which Kavasalas intimated that as a Clergyman he had expected favourable if not indulgent treatment from the present Secretary of the Navy A remark perhaps not unnatural though not very politic for it exasperated Mr. Bancroft who thereupon told him that he saw himself his incompetency for
a teacher in the Navy of the United States— After this unfortunate allusion it is apparent that I can do nothing further for this poor man and that he must submit with as much of christian resignation as he can to his fate— The Turks at Smyrna are not more inexorable to his Father and Mother, than a Christian Divine turned into a Secretary of the Navy will be to him— At twelve oclock I attended the Meeting of the House with the expectation of an immediate adjournment but a sparring debate of between two and three hours was sprung upon the motion to proceed to the election of a Superintendant of the Folding room an Officer not recognised by Law or even by the rules of the House, appointed hitherto as a Subordinate of the Doorkeeper by him, but which the House have now determined to appoint by their own election— There was a conflict of Patronage between some of the leading Members of the House at work to animate and prolong this Debate— A Grave question was discussed whether the Election should be made as now usual viva voce or by Tellers— A question which remained undecided in as much as after several motions for adjournment one finally succeeded by Yeas and Nays— While this debate was in progress a Bill came in from the Senate for extending the Laws of the United States over the State of Texas, an effort was made to pass it through the House per saltum, but it was finally referred to the Committee on the Judiciary—

I attended Public worship in the Hall of the House Representatives where the Chaplain of the House Mr.Milburn preached from 1. Romans 15. “So as much as in me is I am ready to preach the Gospel to you that are at Rome also” a text in which and in its application to the Preacher himself there was to say the least no small portion for presumption He introduced the Discourse with a very detailed byographical account of St Paul the Author of the Epistles to the Romans—beginning with his birth and origen, His education at the feet of Gamaliel. His early hostility to the Christians, his keeping of the garments of the Ruffians who murdered the first Martyr Stephen—his commission from the High Priest breathing out threatnings and slaughter against the Diciples of the Lord—on his way to Damascus, the sudden and miraculous appearance of Jesus Christ to him on his Journey and its consequences, his conversion and metamorphosis from Saul the persecutor of Jesus, into Paul the great and unrivalled Apostle of the Gentiles— Mr. Milburn in a striking and some what dramatic manner followed him step by step through the whole career of his existence noticing his various Journeys his wonderful adventures and the final elevation of his character to that of an inspired teacher in his Letter to the Romans—then Masters of the World— This narrative well composed
and not ineloquently delivered would have been more interesting but for the seeming arrogance not even veiled or disguised of its application to the Preacher himself who rather intimated than left it to be inferred by his hearers that he himself from a very obscure origin—and under the affliction of almost total blindness had risen from one of the humblest Preachers of the Gospel until brought here by the election of the House of Representatives to Preach the Gospel to them the Rulers of the land, if not the Masters of the World— Mr. Milburne is a Methodist and his manner of Discoursing declamatory as is that of all Preachers of that Denomination has the peculiarity of a very modest introduction and temperate progress diversified with very loud intonations of voice and bursts of spontaneous declamation— I walked home and in the afternoon attended at Saint Johns Church where the Revd. Mr. Pyne—read the evening service for the Sunday after Christmas and preached from Luke 4.18. part of the verse “He has sent me to preach deliverance to the captives and recovering of sight to the blind.” This is only a part of a verse containing the self anunciation of Jesus Christ of himself as the Messiah in the Synagogue on the Sabbath day at Nazareth— It is the passage of al most awful solemnity in the whole Bible— The text is part of the passage which he read from the Book of Isaiah which after reading he closed the Book and sat down saying this day is this scripture fulfilled in your ears— It is impossible to treat this subject as it should be treated without taking together the narrative of the event the words which Jesus read from the Book of Isaiah and this assertion immediately following that he was the fulfilment of that prophecy— Let me here repeat the whole of the Passage which he read as recorded here by the Apostle Luke— “The spirit of the Lord is upon me because He hath anointed me to preach the Gospel to the poor. He hath sent me to heal the broken hearted, to preach deliverance to the Captives, and recovering of sight to the blind, to set at Liberty them that are bruised to preach the acceptable year of the Lord” The passage in the Book of Isaiah thus quoted by the Saviour is the first and second verses of the 61. Chap. where it reads thus “the spirit of the Lord God is upon me because the Lord hath anointed me to preach good tidings unto the meek he hath sent me to bind up the broken hearted to proclaim liberty to the captives and the opening of the Prison to them that are bound—to proclaim the acceptable year of the Lord.” thus far is the passage read by Jesus Christ, as related, in the narrative of St Luke— There are several remarkable differences between
the translation from the Hebrew of Isaiah in the English Bible and that from the Greek of St Luke in the New Testament In the Book of Isaiah—the apparent purport of the Chapter refers only to the Prophet himself and continues to declare the purpose of his own commission in its essence and its consequences through the whole Chapter— In the narrative of Luke Jesus declares, that this Prophecy of Isaiah is fulfilled in him but in this proclamation of his Commission he stops in the midst of the 2d. verse of the Commission, unfolded by the Prophet Isaiah leaving out all the remnant of that Chapter— Mr. Pyne contracted still more the theme of his Discourse by confining his text to a part of the commission proclaimed by the Saviour consisting only in preaching deliverance to the captives and of recovering of sight to the blind an incident not even contained in the passage from Isaiah as it now stands in the English translation of the Bible a complete commentary upon this declaration by Jesus Christ of his whole commission from Heaven compared with this Prophecy of it in the Book of Isaiah is much to be desired, but this Discourse of Mr. Pyne commenting only upon a fragment in which the Old and New Testament are not identical leaves that exposition still to be desired— Mr. Richard Cutts and his sister Mary were here this evening and also Mr. John Connell from Philadelphia—

Mrs. Beck was here with a Petition for a Pension was a daughter one of the Pensioners of the Revolutionary War— But no Petitions were received by the House where immediately after the reading of the Journal Tibbats of Kentucky moved the suspension of the order of the day to introduce notices of Bills. Bills, and Resolutions of Instructions to Committees on taking the Question there was no quorum in the House to vote upon the motion. A Call of the House was moved and refused the appointment of a Superintendant of the Folding Room was resumed Preston King had moved last Friday that the whole subject should be referred to the Committee on Accounts with instructions to Report what effect the proposed change would have on the expenses of the House and the convenience of its Members— The Previous Question was moved and refused Thomas Smith moved to lay the whole subject on the Table rejected by yeas and nays, 68. to 76—the referrence to the Committee on Accounts, was rejected by Tellers
59. to 82. McKay moved the referrence to a select Committee and in the mean time to postpone the election of the superintendant which after a long Debate and various instructions to the Committee was carried— A message was received from the President relating to the expenditures of the late mission to China—a joint Resolution respecting the preparation of the by anRegister, was read a third time, and after some Debate on a proposed amendment referred to the Committee on Naval Affairs, the Debate on the Resolutions from the Legislature of Massachusetts concerning the Naturalization Laws was then resumed and Washington Hunt of New York made an hour speech to defend the Whigs against the charge of having countenanced or being in any manner connected with the Native American Party after which just before three o’clock the House adjourned— Mr. James H Murdock who some time since had requested my Autograph for nine ladies of Connecticut and Georgia called and I delivered them to him—these Ladies were.

div.p:
Mr. Caleb Cushing was also here—and had much conversation with me He said he was here only for two or three days upon some business of his own the nature of which he did not tell me— He said that we were coming again to the times of the Panama Mission which I told him I did not understand— He made inquires concerning the right of Intervention and whether according to International Law Blockades could be instituted unless between Parties are War— I supposed he had referrence to a Blockade of the Platte river said to have been proclaimed jointly by a French and British Squadron off Montevideo—and I conjectured that there was some question in our present Executive Administration—depending at the present time—and that Mr. Cushing was under an expectation of a Diplomatic Mission connected therewith— We had also some desultary conversation respecting his late Mission to China— I mentioned the Lecture which I delivered in 1842. at Boston—
concerning the War then existing between Great Britain and China in which I had avowed the opinion that in that War the right was on the side of Great Britain— That after his return from China I had heard that he in a Lecture delivered at Boston had expressed an opinion adverse to mine but was afterwards told, that he had contradicted this Statement—he said it was so that on reading my Lecture he had procured the papers laid before the British Parliament upon which my opinion had been formed and that he fully concurred with it— I asked him some questions respecting the Religion of the Chineese and their system of morals and whether among them there were any Mahometans he said there were some Mahometans among the Tartars—but of the Chinees there was very little religion excepting Confucianism. I observed that there were differences of international Law between nations modified by their systems of Religion that between Christian nations there was one system founded upon the fundamental Moral Principle of Christianity brotherly Love among men, there was another system between Christian and Mahometan nations modified by the Mahometan Principle the Unity of God and the creed that Mahomet is his Prophet with the further doctrine that this Creed may be imposed upon the rest of mankind by force—that there was still another system with the Chinees, and I asked what was the fundamental principle of morals with them? he said it was the relation of authority and obedience, between Parent and Child, he said also that the words of Jesus upon the Cross “Father forgive them for they know not what they do” were to the very letter in the Cyropædia of Zenophon and he intimated that the Christian Doctrine was fully comprised in the discourses of Socrates—which I think is not quite correct—

I had a night, of quiet repose and sound sleep till past five this morning but I am suffering severely with a flying rheumatism and the involuntary tremulous agitation of my nerves bears me down with increasing vigour— I think it was never so great as this morning a potion of salts gave me but very partial relief— Mrs. Beck of Charlestown was here—impatient not merely for the presentation
of her Petition but for the immediate enactment of a Special Law in her favour— She said it was a great inconvenience to her to be kept here a burden upon her friends— I told her that on the very first day upon which the House would receive Petitions I would present hers and I wished I could encourage her to expect an early decision upon it—but from all the experience that I had had upon the most successful Petitions for private Claims—I must confess—that she could have no hope of relief from that source within less than three or four months— That I did not believe she could advance it one hour by remaining here that her Petition when presented would be referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Claims who if upon examination should be satisfied of its justice would Report in its favor but this in the most prosperous state of things could not be obtained within many weeks and if they should Report in its favor there would be many weeks more before the House could pass upon it and then it would have to go through a like proceeding in the Senate—that there could be no use of her remaining here as her presence would not advance it for a day— If she thought it necessary to stay till she could see the Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Claims to whom it would be referred I should advise her immediately afterwards to return home and await the decision there— If she would call again tomorrow morning I would inform her of the name of the Chairman of that Committee, whom if she thought proper she could call and see before her departure.— At the House, a Select Committee of five on the folding Room and all its apertenences and announced with McKay of North Carolina for Chairman and the Debate on the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts concerning the naturalization Laws consumed the remainder of the day and Speeches against the Native American Party followed in succession from Douglass of Illinois, Bedinger of Virginia Simms of South Carolina and James Dixon of Connecticut, Joseph R Ingersoll of Philadelphia and Brodhead of the same state and Hamlin of Maine consumed the remnant of the day. After which the Massachusett Resolutions were referred to the Committee on the Judiciary— Garrett Davis offered certain Resolutions for the investigation by the Committee on the Judiciary of the Defalcation of the late Clerk of the House Caleb. J. McNulty—which were adopted— There were five inditments against him in the United States Circuit Court for this District upon one of which he has been tried and acquitted by verdict of a Jury
a Nolle prosequi has been entered upon the other four One of Mr. Davis’ Resolutions implies that the mode summoning and empanelling Juries in the Courts of the United States—have contributed to the acquittal of Mr. McNulty and required an Amendment of the Law— A Report was received from the secretary of the Treasury in answer to a Resolution inquiring why certain Sums of Money due to the state of Arkansas had been with held from payment and the answer is that it has been by virtue of Joint Resolution of the 3d. March last providing that whenever any State shall have been or may be in default for the payment of interest or Principle on investments in its Stock or Bonds held by the United States in trust it shall be the duty of the Secretary of the Treasury to retain the whole or so much thereof as may be necessary of the percentage to which such state may be entitled of the proceeds of the sales of the Public Lands within its limits and apply the same to the payment of said interest or principle or to the reimbursement of any Sums of Money expended by the United States for that purpose— This provision was first introduced into an Act of Congress by me in 1842 and is the only check which I believe practicable to an enormous system of swindling and plunder by some of the Democratic States upon the Treasury of the Union— The speaker said that the first business of tomorrow would be the Call of the Committees for Reports— Adjourned about 3. o’clock— The first symptom of the first present Administration flinching in the controversy with Great Britain concerning the Oregon Question occurred in the Senate this day—upon certain Resolutions offered by Hannegan Senator from Indiana reasserting the right of this Country to the whole of Oregon to which Amendments offered by John. C. Calhoun declaring the subject still open for negotiation and looking to a renewal of the offer of the 49. Parof Latitude for the boundary— Hannegans Resolutions were at his own motion laid on the Table for further discussion hereafter—

Mrs. Beck came again this morning and I informed her that no Petitions, had been received by the House yesterday and none would probably be received this day— that
from this time the first thirty days of the Session having expired only one day in the week would be assigned for the receipt of Petitions and that the opportunity of presenting hers would not occur till next Monday— I gave her the name of the Chairman of the Committee on Revolutionary Claims—Joseph Johnson of Va and of the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions Richard Brodhead of Pa— That to one or the other of these Committees her Petition would doubtless be referred but that no possible benefit could accrue to her from her remaining here, and I advised her to return home as soon as possible— She mentioned her need, of the means of defraying her passage for which I gave her five dollars—which she promised to return if she should ever be able— At the House, the day was chiefly consumed in the Call of Committees for Reports—and a Debate upon a proposition for printing an additional number of Fremont’s Report to supply the new members of the present Congress with a number of Copies equal to those distributed by a Resolution of the last Session to the Members of the 28th. Congress. A joint Resolution was passed reported by McKay Chairman of the Committee Ways and Means that it shall be the duty of the Secretary of the Treasury to cause the Annual estimates, to be printed and copies to be delivered to the Clerk of the House in time for distribution at the Commencement of each Session—among the Reports was one by John W. Tibbatts from the Committee on Commerce a Bill making Appropriations for the improvement of certain Harbours and Rivers—when upon his motion to commit the Bill to the committee of the whole on the State of the Union Crossier of Tennessee moved instructions to the Committee to amend the Bill by inserting a Clause making an Appropriation of one hundred thousand dollars for the improvement of the Tennessee River— This was followed by a long Debate chiefly upon the Question on the rule that all Appropriations of Money should first be considered in Committee on the Whole. This Rule furtherly prevailed and the Bill was referred to Committee of the Whole on the state of the Union without instructions— Mr. Vantz of Ohio moved that when the House should adjourn it should be till Saturday, but this was objected to and the yeas and nays were called where upon Vantz modified his Resolution to adjourn over till Friday which passed without opposition— There were several Reports relating to Oregon and the Indians—
A Prayer—

lg.l: —composed in the sleepless hours of last Christmas night—
O Lord my God! of boundless might possess’d
In mercy sooth the tremblings of my breast!
For all the trials I am doom’d to bear,
My Soul submissive to the will prepare—
Through the long night of balmy sleep bereft
Howeer distress’d let Patience still be left
Patience with calm composure to endure
Woes which no human aid or skill can cure
My Wife, my offspring all whose fates depend
On me, Oh may they find in thee a friend
Whateer of blessing is to me denied
For them O gracious God! Thyself provide
And when thy wisdom shall arrest my breath,
Fit me to meet for ere thy face in death.

div.p: —Washington 31. December 1845.
